article.title: Roll maneuvers are essential for active reorientation of Caenorhabditis elegans in 3D media
funding: Texas Tech University Doctoral Dissertation Completion Fellowship
article.abstract: Locomotion of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is a key observable used in investigations ranging from behavior to neuroscience to aging. However, while the natural environment of this model organism is 3D, quantitative investigations of its locomotion have been mostly limited to 2D motion.

sections.methods: Wild-type C. elegans were used to record the 3D swimming. Worms were cultured in a nematode growth medium plate seeded with the bacteria Escherichia coli OP50 at 20 Â°C.
sections.discussion: Based on our investigation of available stereoscopic images and other experimental evidence, we have shown that C. elegans explore their 3D environment by combining planar turns with roll reorientation maneuvers.

article.insights_summary: C. elegans explore their 3D environment by combining planar turns with roll reorientation maneuvers. The rolls, during which the undulation plane of the worm rotates about the trajectory axis, constitute an important previously unrecognized behavioral pattern that is an essential component of 3D locomotion.
